## Post‑licensure (Phase 4) safety monitoring – how it works  

When a childhood vaccine is licensed, the **“safety story” does not end** with the Phase 3 trial.  Millions of doses are given in routine immunisation programmes, and a layered surveillance system is used to detect **rare** (≤ 1 in 10 000–1 in 1 000 000) or **delayed** adverse events that could not be seen in the controlled trial.  Below is a step‑by‑step description of the main components that are in place in the United States, Europe, and globally, followed by the specific rare‑event data that have emerged for the **acellular DTaP** vaccine after > 300 million doses have been administered worldwide.

---

### 1.  Passive (spontaneous‑report) systems  

| System | Who runs it | What it captures | Strengths | Limitations |
|--------|-------------|------------------|-----------|-------------|
| **VAERS** (Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System) – US | CDC & FDA | Any health event that occurs after vaccination, reported by clinicians, patients, or manufacturers. | Very broad; captures signals that would be missed in formal studies; free‑text allows novel syndromes to appear. | Under‑reporting (estimates 1–10 % of events reported); no denominator (cannot give incidence without external data); reports are not verified causality. |
| **Yellow Card Scheme** – UK | MHRA (Medicines & Healthcare products Regulatory Agency) | Similar to VAERS; includes electronic and paper forms. | Long history (since 1960s); integrates with NHS data for follow‑up. | Same under‑reporting issues. |
| **EudraVigilance** – EU | European Medicines Agency (EMA) | Centralised database for all EU member states; includes serious and non‑serious reports. | Allows cross‑country signal detection; mandatory reporting of serious events by manufacturers. | Variable reporting quality across countries. |
| **VigiBase** – WHO global | Uppsala Monitoring Centre (UMC) | > 30 million individual case safety reports from > 130 countries. | Global perspective; can spot rare events that appear only when many doses are pooled. | Heterogeneity of data; time lag for data entry. |

**How rare‑event signals are identified**

1. **Disproportionality analysis** – statistical methods (e.g., Reporting Odds Ratio, Proportional Reporting Ratio) compare how often a specific event is reported with a given vaccine versus all other vaccines.  
2. **Temporal clustering** – algorithms look for spikes in reports within a narrow time window after immunisation.  
3. **Clinical review** – pharmacovigilance teams (CDC, EMA, national regulators) review the medical records of flagged cases to assess plausibility and rule out confounders.

If a signal looks credible, the next step is **active surveillance** (see below) to estimate the true incidence.
